newsitem.title: USA: US mortgage-backeds whacked in pre-holiday trade.
newsitem.headline: US mortgage-backeds whacked in pre-holiday trade.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities spent New Year's Eve in the doldrums, as pass-through prices skidded lower in line with Treasuries.
Treasuries and pass-through prices fell sharply following the release of much stronger-than-expected new home sales figures, traders said.
Also, the Conference Board released a report that showed consumer confidence rose to 113.8 in December from 109.5 in November.
Securities firms operated with skeleton crews as market players fled their posts early for the New Year holiday.
The few traders at work said they couldn't find any inspiration amid Tuesday morning's economic data.
"We're down with Treasuries," said one New York-based trader. "That's the only thing going on today. No activity here," he said.
By early afternoon Tuesday, pass-throughs were 2/32 to 23/32 lower.
Specifically, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5 percent paper was down 19/32 at 100-00/32, yielding 115 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae 7.5 percent coupons dropped 15/32 to 100-00/32, and Freddie Mac 7.5 percent coupons were off 17/32 to 100-03/32.
The U.S. bond market and other debt markets will be closing early at 1400 EST/1900 GMT. Markets will be closed Wednesday for New Year's day.
Fresh cash in early 1997 may give mortgage-backeds a boost, traders said. "Particularly in the first day, you are going to see things tighten up pretty good down here," one trader said.
